**Disney Princess** , also called the **Princess Line** ,[2] is a [media
franchise](/wiki/Media_franchise "Media franchise") owned by [The Walt Disney
Company](/wiki/The_Walt_Disney_Company "The Walt Disney Company"). Created by
[Disney Consumer Products](/wiki/Disney_Consumer_Products "Disney Consumer
Products") chairman [Andy Mooney](/wiki/Andy_Mooney "Andy Mooney") in the
early 2000s, the franchise features a line-up of [fictional female
protagonists](/wiki/List_of_Disney_characters_by_film "List of Disney
characters by film") who have appeared in various [Disney
franchises](/wiki/Disney_animated_features_canon "Disney animated features
canon").

The franchise does not include all princess characters from the whole of
Disney-owned media, but rather refers to specific characters from the
company's animated films. As of
2017[[update]](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Disney_Princess&action=edit),
the eleven characters considered part of the franchise are [Snow
White](/wiki/Snow_White_\(Disney_character\) "Snow White \(Disney
character\)"), [Cinderella](/wiki/Cinderella_\(Disney_character\) "Cinderella
\(Disney character\)"), [Aurora](/wiki/Aurora_\(Disney_character\) "Aurora
\(Disney character\)"), [Ariel](/wiki/Ariel_\(Disney\) "Ariel \(Disney\)"),
[Belle](/wiki/Belle_\(Disney\) "Belle \(Disney\)"),
[Jasmine](/wiki/Princess_Jasmine "Princess Jasmine"),
[Pocahontas](/wiki/Pocahontas_\(character\) "Pocahontas \(character\)"),
[Mulan](/wiki/Mulan_\(Disney_character\) "Mulan \(Disney character\)"),
[Tiana](/wiki/Tiana_\(Disney\) "Tiana \(Disney\)"),
[Rapunzel](/wiki/Rapunzel_\(Disney\) "Rapunzel \(Disney\)"), and
[Merida](/wiki/Merida_\(Disney\) "Merida \(Disney\)").[3][4]

The franchise has released dolls, sing-along videos, apparel, home decor,
toys, and a variety of other products featuring some of the Disney
Princesses.[5] Licensees for the franchise include
[Glidden](/wiki/Glidden_\(paints\) "Glidden \(paints\)") (wall paint), [Stride
Rite](/wiki/Stride_Rite "Stride Rite") (sparkly shoes), [Hasbro](/wiki/Hasbro
"Hasbro") (games and dolls), and plastic [Fisher-Price](/wiki/Fisher-Price
"Fisher-Price") figurines.[6]

## History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Disney_Princess&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: History")]

### Conception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Disney_Princess&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Conception")]

Standing in line in the arena [of a [Disney on Ice](/wiki/Disney_on_Ice
"Disney on Ice") show], I was surrounded by little girls dressed head to toe
as princesses...They weren’t even Disney products. They were generic princess
products they’d appended to a Halloween costume. And the light bulb went off.
Clearly, there was latent demand here. So the next morning I said to my team,
"O.K., let's establish standards and a color palette and talk to licensees and
get as much product out there as we possibly can that allows these girls to do
what they're doing anyway: projecting themselves into the characters from the
classic movies."

—Mooney, on his creation of the Disney Princess franchise as reported by _[The
New York Times](/wiki/The_New_York_Times "The New York Times")_[7]

Former [Nike, Inc.](/wiki/Nike,_Inc. "Nike, Inc.") executive [Andy
Mooney](/wiki/Andy_Mooney "Andy Mooney") was appointed chairman of [The Walt
Disney Company](/wiki/The_Walt_Disney_Company "The Walt Disney Company")'s
[Disney Consumer Products](/wiki/Disney_Consumer_Products "Disney Consumer
Products") division in the late 1990s.[7][8] While attending his first [Disney
on Ice](/wiki/Disney_on_Ice "Disney on Ice") show, Mooney noticed that several
young girls attending the show were dressed in princess attire that were not
authentic Disney products.[9] "They were generic princess products they’d
appended to a Halloween costume," Mooney told _[The New York
Times](/wiki/The_New_York_Times "The New York Times")_. Concerned by this,
Mooney addressed the company the following morning and encouraged them to
commence work on a legitimate Disney Princess franchise in January 2000.[7]
Walt's nephew, [Roy E. Disney](/wiki/Roy_E._Disney "Roy E. Disney"), objected
to the creation of the line, as the company has long "avoided mingling
characters from its classic fairy tales in other narratives, worrying that it
would weaken the individual mythologies".[2]

The original line-up consisted of princesses [Snow
White](/wiki/Snow_White_\(Disney_character\) "Snow White \(Disney
character\)"), [Cinderella](/wiki/Cinderella_\(Disney_character\) "Cinderella
\(Disney character\)"), [Aurora](/wiki/Aurora_\(Disney_character\) "Aurora
\(Disney character\)"), [Ariel](/wiki/Ariel_\(Disney\) "Ariel \(Disney\)"),
[Belle](/wiki/Belle_\(Disney\) "Belle \(Disney\)"),
[Jasmine](/wiki/Princess_Jasmine "Princess Jasmine"),
[Pocahontas](/wiki/Pocahontas_\(character\) "Pocahontas \(character\)"),
[Mulan](/wiki/Mulan_\(Disney_character\) "Mulan \(Disney character\)") and
[Tinker Bell](/wiki/Tinker_Bell "Tinker Bell"). Five of them (Snow White,
Aurora, Jasmine, Pocahontas, and Ariel) were royal by blood, two (Cinderella
and Belle) married into royalty, and two (Mulan and Tinker Bell) fit the
"princess mythology." Tinker Bell was soon removed from the latter category
and the overall line-up. This was the first time the characters would be
marketed in a separate franchise than their original films. Mooney decided
that, when featured on marketing advertisements such as posters, the
princesses should never make eye contact with each other in an attempt to keep
their individual "mythologies" intact. "[Each] stares off in a slightly
different direction as if unaware of the others' presence."[7]

In an unconventional manner, Mooney and his team launched the Disney Princess
line without utilizing any [focus groups](/wiki/Focus_group "Focus group") and
with minimal marketing. By 2001, Disney Consumer Products (DCP) generated
about 300 million dollars, but by 2012, the division had increased revenue to
3 billion dollars, making it the top seller of consumer entertainment products
globally.[10] DCP issued princess product licenses to Hasbro for games, Mattel
dolls, and plastic Fisher-Price figurines in 2000, allowing the franchise to
meet the $1 billion mark in revenue in three years.[6]

### Expansions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Disney_Princess&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Expansions")]

Tiana became the first additional character to the Princess franchise
officially on March 14, 2010, taking Tinker Bell's short-lived place as the
ninth member. Her coronation took place at the [New York
Palace](/wiki/Lotte_New_York_Palace_Hotel "Lotte New York Palace Hotel").[11]
Tinker Bell was already heading up another franchise started in 2005, [Disney
Fairies](/wiki/Disney_Fairies "Disney Fairies").[12]

Rapunzel was "[crowned](/wiki/Coronation "Coronation")" and inducted into the
Disney Princess franchise as the tenth member on October 2, 2011, at
[Kensington Palace](/wiki/Kensington_Palace "Kensington Palace") in [London,
England](/wiki/London,_England "London, England").[13] On May 11, 2013, Disney
added the first [Pixar](/wiki/Pixar "Pixar") character Merida as the 11th
Princess to the franchise in a coronation ceremony in front of Cinderella
Castle at [Magic Kingdom](/wiki/Magic_Kingdom "Magic Kingdom") in [Walt Disney
World](/wiki/Walt_Disney_World "Walt Disney World").[3]

With [Target Corporation](/wiki/Target_Corporation "Target Corporation") as
its marketing partner, Disney held the first National Princess Week the week
of April 22, 2012. During the week, there was the release of _[The Princess
Diaries](/wiki/The_Princess_Diaries_\(film\) "The Princess Diaries \(film\)")_
Blu-ray and _The Very Fairy Princess_ book.[14] Harrod, already have a [Disney
stores](/wiki/Disney_Store#Disney_at_Harrods "Disney Store") within, followed
with their Christmas theme being Disney Princess by having Oscar de la Renta
designed dress for the Princess on display.[15] In August, the dress were on
display at [D23 Expo](/wiki/D23_\(Disney\) "D23 \(Disney\)") before being
auctioned on November 13 to benefit [Great Ormond Street Hospital Children's
Charity](/wiki/Great_Ormond_Street_Hospital_Children%27s_Charity "Great Ormond
Street Hospital Children's Charity").[16]

[Mattel](/wiki/Mattel "Mattel") adding a Barbie princess-themed line in
late-2010 then the fair and fantasy store based _[Ever After
High](/wiki/Ever_After_High "Ever After High")_ in 2013. Mattel was only
putting out Princesses Cinderella, Ariel and Belle plus Anna and Elsa during
the last year or so of its license. With these competing lines and an
expiration of the brand license at the end of 2015, Disney gave
[Hasbro](/wiki/Hasbro "Hasbro") a chance to gain the license given their work
on Star Wars which lead to a _[Descendants](/wiki/Descendants_\(2015_film\)
"Descendants \(2015 film\)")_ license. DCP was also attempting to evolve the
brand by making them less as damsels and more as heroines. In September 2014,
Disney announced that Hasbro would be the licensed doll maker for the Disney
Princess line starting on January 1, 2016.[6]

The June 2013 release of the Disney Princess Palace Pets app from Disney
Publishing, led DCP to turn Palace Pets into a Disney Princess franchise
extension, with the release of The Palace Pets toy line in August from
licensee [Blip Toys](/w/index.php?title=Blip_Toys&action=edit&redlink=1 "Blip
Toys \(page does not exist\)"). The line was also selected by
TimetoPlayMag.com for its Most Wanted List Holiday 2013.[1] In 2015 Disney
Publishing released animated shorts series _[Whisker Haven Tales with the
Palace Pets](/wiki/Whisker_Haven_Tales_with_the_Palace_Pets "Whisker Haven
Tales with the Palace Pets")_. The shorts journey to a magical world of
Whisker Haven, a secret realm located in a fairy-tale space between the Disney
Princess kingdoms.[17]

## Disney
Princesses[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Disney_Princess&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Disney Princesses")]

Princesses were given an official number in the franchise lineup starting with
Snow White as the first and original Disney princess, with Cinderella being
the second, followed by Aurora and so on.[18]

### Classic
era[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Disney_Princess&action=edit&section=5 "Edit
section: Classic era")]

#### Snow
White[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Disney_Princess&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: Snow White")]

Main article: [Snow White (Disney
character)](/wiki/Snow_White_\(Disney_character\) "Snow White \(Disney
character\)")

[Snow White](/wiki/Snow_White_\(Disney_character\) "Snow White \(Disney
character\)") is the first and original Disney Princess.[18] A main character
in [Walt Disney Animation Studios](/wiki/Walt_Disney_Animation_Studios "Walt
Disney Animation Studios")' 1st animated feature film _[Snow White and the
Seven Dwarfs](/wiki/Snow_White_and_the_Seven_Dwarfs_\(1937_film\) "Snow White
and the Seven Dwarfs \(1937 film\)")_ (1937), Snow White is a beautiful young
princess, described by her evil stepmother's Magic Mirror as having 'hair as
black as ebony, lips as red as the rose, skin as white as snow' and also
dubbed by the Mirror as the 'Fairest Of Them All'.[19] She is forced to seek
refuge in the home of the [seven dwarfs](/wiki/Seven_Dwarfs "Seven Dwarfs")
where she hides from her evil stepmother, [Queen
Grimhilde](/wiki/Queen_Grimhilde "Queen Grimhilde"), who got angered by the
fact that Snow White's beauty was greater than hers. She asked the Huntsman to
kill the princess; however, as an act of pity, he ends up setting her free and
telling her the Evil Queen's plan. Snow White is often described as a kind,
optimistic, tidy and happy person who sees the good in everyone. Originally
voiced by [Adriana Caselotti](/wiki/Adriana_Caselotti "Adriana Caselotti") and
animated by [Marc Davis](/wiki/Marc_Davis_\(animator\) "Marc Davis
\(animator\)") and [Les Clark](/wiki/Les_Clark "Les Clark"), she and her movie
are based on the heroine and story of the German fairy tale _[Snow
White](/wiki/Snow_White "Snow White")_ (1812) by the [Brothers
Grimm](/wiki/Brothers_Grimm "Brothers Grimm"). She has also been voiced by
[Mary Kay Bergman](/wiki/Mary_Kay_Bergman "Mary Kay Bergman"), Carolyn
Gardener, and most recently Katherine Von Till. A crisp, blood red apple has
become her trademark with years of exposure.

Snow White is often known as one of the most anti-feminist Disney princesses
through her goodness, which leads to passivity, her living with the [Seven
Dwarfs](/wiki/Seven_Dwarfs "Seven Dwarfs"), her tendency to clean, and her
awaiting of a prince to save her from her oppressions, which critics have
viewed as [misogyny](/wiki/Misogyny "Misogyny") and a danger to young women
who will want to replicate these behaviors in their own lives.[20][21] While
many argue that she was a reflection of the era in which she was created,
others claim that the complexity of animation of the time made it too
difficult to add complexity to the characters in the film. Janet Maslin of
[The New York Times](/wiki/The_New_York_Times "The New York Times") claims,
"Aside from her great daintiness and her credentials as a fervent housekeeper,
Snow White has no distinct personality. She exists only to be victimized by
her wicked stepmother - a far more interesting character - and to wait for Mr.
Right," that supports feminist theory,[22] but despite public feminist
responses to the character, Disney regards Snow White as kind, sweet and
respectful, encouraging children to, "be a friend to all," in the same way she
is depicted in the film.[23]

####
Cinderella[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Disney_Princess&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Cinderella")]

Main article: [Cinderella (Disney
character)](/wiki/Cinderella_\(Disney_character\) "Cinderella \(Disney
character\)")

[Cinderella](/wiki/Cinderella_\(Disney_character\) "Cinderella \(Disney
character\)") is the second Disney Princess.[18] Her movie, Disney's 12th
animated feature film, is named after her,
_[Cinderella](/wiki/Cinderella_\(1950_film\) "Cinderella \(1950 film\)")_ ,
released in 1950. She is often considered the "Leader of the Disney
Princesses". Forced into servitude by her evil stepmother, [Lady
Tremaine](/wiki/List_of_Disney%27s_Cinderella_characters#Lady_Tremaine "List
of Disney's Cinderella characters"), and her two cruel stepsisters,
[Drizella](/wiki/List_of_Disney%27s_Cinderella_characters#Drizella_Tremaine
"List of Disney's Cinderella characters") and
[Anastasia](/wiki/List_of_Disney%27s_Cinderella_characters#Anastasia_Tremaine
"List of Disney's Cinderella characters"), after her father's death, her only
source of happiness was her animal friends, which consists of birds and mice.
While scrubbing the floors of her late father's mansion, an invitation to the
Prince's ball is delivered, inviting all of the eligible women to attend so
that he can find a wife. While Cinderella meets the requirements to attend,
her stepfamily forbids her, going so far as to rip apart the clothes that the
mice and birds had created for her as the carriage arrives. When all seems
lost, her [fairy
godmother](/wiki/List_of_Disney%27s_Cinderella_characters#Fairy_Godmother
"List of Disney's Cinderella characters") gives her the means to attend, where
she falls in love with [the
Prince](/wiki/List_of_Disney%27s_Cinderella_characters#Prince_Charming "List
of Disney's Cinderella characters").

Cinderella is based on the heroine of the French fairy tale
_[Cinderella](/wiki/Cinderella#Plot "Cinderella")_ by [Charles
Perrault](/wiki/Charles_Perrault "Charles Perrault") and the German fairy tale
Ashputtel by the Brothers Grimm. Originally voiced by [Ilene
Woods](/wiki/Ilene_Woods "Ilene Woods") and animated by [Marc
Davis](/wiki/Marc_Davis_\(animator\) "Marc Davis \(animator\)"), in recent
animated features she is currently voiced by [Jennifer
Hale](/wiki/Jennifer_Hale "Jennifer Hale"). In the original movie,
Cinderella's hair was intended to be more of a strawberry-blonde color, but
today she is depicted as having blonde hair. Also, her iconic [ball
gown](/wiki/Ball_gown "Ball gown") is depicted as light blue instead of silver
in nearly all media and merchandise. Cinderella is also known as "Cinderelly"
by the mice. These days, her legendary glass slipper, which was used by the
Prince to find her, symbolizes Cinderella's timeless character and tale.

As part of a new launch of live-action Disney classic recreation films,
Cinderella was portrayed by [Lily James](/wiki/Lily_James "Lily James") in the
[2015 motion-picture](/wiki/Cinderella_\(2015_Disney_film\) "Cinderella \(2015
Disney film\)"). The film is commended for remaining close to the original
plot line of the animated feature supplemented by added depth to give the
original character more background and dimension. Reviews cite the movie's
usage of the mantra, "have courage and be kind" ("But at least [Cinderella's]
outward beauty is poignantly augmented by an inner kindness and courage,
things she manages to hold on to despite the abuses heaped upon her by her
stepmother and stepsisters"),[24] claiming it to support and to help modern
audiences reinvigorate their admiration of one of the earliest Disney
princesses.

Like Snow White, Cinderella faces feminist criticism for chasing after a man
for freedom, displaying household chores, and means of beauty as the only way
to attract a man that viewers may see the need to perpetuate.[25] Disney,
however, cites Cinderella as a persistent princess in the light of injustice,
believing she sends the message to "never give up."[26]

#### Aurora[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Disney_Princess&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Aurora")]

Main article: [Aurora (Disney character)](/wiki/Aurora_\(Disney_character\)
"Aurora \(Disney character\)")

[Aurora](/wiki/Aurora_\(Disney_character\) "Aurora \(Disney character\)"),
originally voiced by [Mary Costa](/wiki/Mary_Costa "Mary Costa"), is the third
Disney Princess.[18] She first appeared in Disney's 16th animated feature film
_[Sleeping Beauty](/wiki/Sleeping_Beauty_\(1959_film\) "Sleeping Beauty \(1959
film\)")_ (1959). The motion picture is adapted from the French fairy tale
_[The Sleeping Beauty](/wiki/Sleeping_Beauty "Sleeping Beauty")_ by [Charles
Perrault](/wiki/Charles_Perrault "Charles Perrault") (1697), from the German
fairy tale _[Little Briar Rose](/wiki/Sleeping_Beauty "Sleeping Beauty")_
(1812) by [The Brothers Grimm](/wiki/The_Brothers_Grimm "The Brothers Grimm")
and from _[The Sleeping Beauty](/wiki/The_Sleeping_Beauty_\(ballet\) "The
Sleeping Beauty \(ballet\)")_ ballet by [Pyotr Ilyich
Tchaikovsky](/wiki/Pyotr_Ilyich_Tchaikovsky "Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky")
(1890). Aurora is a princess by birth, daughter of her kingdom's rulers and
betrothed to another kingdom's prince. She is described as having hair of
sunshine gold and lips that shame the red rose; she is also often described as
being kind, shy, sophisticated, and a hopeless romantic. At first, she is seen
as a little naive and insecure as a result of being sheltered for most of her
life but, unlike Snow White, she is somewhat pluckier and more opinionated. In
later media, she is shown to have matured and become more self-assured,
independent and confident. She was later voiced by [Erin
Torpey](/wiki/Erin_Torpey "Erin Torpey") and [Jennifer
Hale](/wiki/Jennifer_Hale "Jennifer Hale"), and is currently voiced by [Kate
Higgins](/wiki/Kate_Higgins "Kate Higgins").

Aurora was also portrayed by [Elle Fanning](/wiki/Elle_Fanning "Elle Fanning")
in the film _[Maleficent](/wiki/Maleficent_\(film\) "Maleficent \(film\)")_ ,
the movie about the fairy's backstory played by [Angelina
Jolie](/wiki/Angelina_Jolie "Angelina Jolie"). This live-action film is a part
of a new series that Disney has been launching in order to give their classic
films modern twists to contemporary audiences.[27]

Like her counterparts in the first wave of animated Disney films, Aurora is
criticized for feminist depictions, mainly in the fact that she had very
little involvement both in the fairy tale and in her own Disney movie, where
Princess Aurora only appears for about 30 minutes. In many bloggers' opinions,
"Aurora in the film is not a person, per se; she is the prize that the other
characters fight over. She is an object, really, and that is not feminist at
all,".[28] Disney, on their Disney princesses website, claims Aurora to
inspire young girls to "always wonder."[29]

### Renaissance
era[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Disney_Princess&action=edit&section=9 "Edit
section: Renaissance era")]

#### Ariel[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Disney_Princess&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Ariel")]

Main article: [Ariel (Disney)](/wiki/Ariel_\(Disney\) "Ariel \(Disney\)")

[Ariel](/wiki/Ariel_\(Disney_character\) "Ariel \(Disney character\)") is the
fourth Disney Princess, as well as the title character in Disney's 28th
animated feature film _[The Little
Mermaid](/wiki/The_Little_Mermaid_\(1989_film\) "The Little Mermaid \(1989
film\)")_ , released in 1989. She is the youngest of [King
Triton](/wiki/King_Triton "King Triton")'s seven daughters. Ariel is a mermaid
princess in the undersea kingdom Atlantica (according to later media in the
franchise). Fascinated by the human world and tired of life under the sea,
Ariel makes a deal with Ursula, an evil sea witch, trading her voice for the
chance to experience the human world. Based on the Danish fairy tale _[The
Little Mermaid](/wiki/The_Little_Mermaid "The Little Mermaid")_ by [Hans
Christian Andersen](/wiki/Hans_Christian_Andersen "Hans Christian Andersen"),
Ariel is voiced by [Jodi Benson](/wiki/Jodi_Benson "Jodi Benson") and animated
by [Glen Keane](/wiki/Glen_Keane "Glen Keane") and [Mark Henn](/wiki/Mark_Henn
"Mark Henn"). The character was inspired by the protagonist in Andersen's
story but was developed into a different personality for the film.[30] Ariel
is fiercely independent and a dreamer, which is notable in her collecting of
human world treasures in her private grotto. She is bold and a risk-taker,
distinguished by her bright red hair, purple/lavender seashell bra and green
tail.

_[The Little Mermaid](/wiki/The_Little_Mermaid_\(1989_film\) "The Little
Mermaid \(1989 film\)")_ was the first animated Disney Princess film following
_[Sleeping Beauty](/wiki/Sleeping_Beauty_\(1959_film\) "Sleeping Beauty \(1959
film\)")_ from 1959.[31] As such, Ariel's film marks a new "Renaissance" of
Disney that created more progressive, independent princesses with higher
levels of depth and complexity.[32] However, of all of the progressive
Princesses, Ariel is regarded as one of the least feminist ones depicted. She
sings "Part of Your World" which pleads for a chance to explore her curiosity
in the outside world, though critics cite that curiosity is largely driven by
her desire to marry a man that she has never even spoken to. However, in
direct contrast to this criticism, Ariel was depicted in the film as being
interested in the human world and species and sang the song long before
falling in love with Eric. Without her voice, many fear that she is reliant on
her beauty and sexuality only and, in the end, is saved by her male lover,
Prince Eric, only to spend the rest of her life on the human world.[33]
Disney, however, claims Ariel spreads a message of, "explor[ing] new
worlds,"[34] that many other viewers notice throughout the film.[35]

#### Belle[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Disney_Princess&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Belle")]

Main article: [Belle (Disney)](/wiki/Belle_\(Disney\) "Belle \(Disney\)")

[Belle](/wiki/Belle_\(Disney\) "Belle \(Disney\)") is the fifth Disney
Princess, first introduced in Disney's 30th animated feature film _[Beauty and
the Beast](/wiki/Beauty_and_the_Beast_\(1991_film\) "Beauty and the Beast
\(1991 film\)")_ (1991). Based on the heroine of the [French fairy
tale](/wiki/Beauty_and_the_Beast "Beauty and the Beast") by [Jeanne-Marie Le
Prince de Beaumont](/wiki/Jeanne-Marie_Le_Prince_de_Beaumont "Jeanne-Marie Le
Prince de Beaumont"), Belle was created by screenwriter [Linda
Woolverton](/wiki/Linda_Woolverton "Linda Woolverton")[36] and originally
animated by [James Baxter](/wiki/James_Baxter_\(animator\) "James Baxter
\(animator\)")[37] and [Mark Henn](/wiki/Mark_Henn "Mark Henn").[38]
Originally voiced by [Paige O'Hara](/wiki/Paige_O%27Hara "Paige O'Hara"),
Belle is currently voiced by [Julie Nathanson](/wiki/Julie_Nathanson "Julie
Nathanson"). O'Hara will, however, return as the voice of Belle in the 2018
film _[Ralph Breaks the Internet: Wreck-It Ralph
2](/wiki/Ralph_Breaks_the_Internet:_Wreck-It_Ralph_2 "Ralph Breaks the
Internet: Wreck-It Ralph 2")_.[39]

Frustrated with her provincial village life, book-loving Belle longs for
adventure. When her father
[Maurice](/wiki/Characters_in_Disney%27s_Beauty_and_the_Beast#Maurice
"Characters in Disney's Beauty and the Beast") is imprisoned by a hideous
[beast](/wiki/Beast_\(Disney_character\) "Beast \(Disney character\)"), Belle
sacrifices her own freedom in return for his. At first frightened by the
Beast's physical appearance and repulsed by his selfishness, Belle learns to
appreciate him after he rescues her from a pack of hungry wolves, expressing
her gratitude by tending to his wounds. While the Beast's love for Belle
gradually results in him adapting a more friendly and civil manner, Belle
befriends him, eventually managing to fall in love with him by the time the
last petal falls off an enchanted rose, which ultimately breaks a spell cast
on him and transforms him back into a handsome prince.

[Emma Watson](/wiki/Emma_Watson "Emma Watson") portrays Belle in the live-
action adaptation, which is also titled _[Beauty and the
Beast](/wiki/Beauty_and_the_Beast_\(2017_film\) "Beauty and the Beast \(2017
film\)")_. This live-action film is a part of a new series that Disney has
been launching in order to give their classic films modern twists to
contemporary audiences.[40]

Personality-wise, Belle has been regarded as an independent,[41]
intelligent,[42] courageous[43] and headstrong,[44] as well as a
[feminist](/wiki/Feminist "Feminist").[45] The character has been universally
lauded by critics, garnering specific praise and recognition for her
intelligence and bravery. The _[Los Angeles Times](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Times
"Los Angeles Times")_ hailed Belle as one of the Disney Princesses responsible
for "break[ing] the bonds of convention".[46] _[The Globe and
Mail](/wiki/The_Globe_and_Mail "The Globe and Mail")_ praised the character,
complimenting her intellect and labeling her the "main attraction of _Beauty
and the Beast_ ".[47] _[Entertainment Weekly](/wiki/Entertainment_Weekly
"Entertainment Weekly")_ highlighted the character's independence, calling her
"the hero" of the film and accrediting her with making _Beauty and the Beast_
the best Disney Princess film.[48] _[The Washington
Post](/wiki/The_Washington_Post "The Washington Post")_ described Belle as
"more mature, more womanly and less blandly [asexual](/wiki/Asexuality
"Asexuality")" than previous Disney heroines.[49] The [American Film
Institute](/wiki/American_Film_Institute "American Film Institute") nominated
Belle for its list of [100 Years...100 Heroes and
Villains](/wiki/AFI%27s_100_Years...100_Heroes_and_Villains "AFI's 100
Years...100 Heroes and Villains").[50] Belle remains the best-received Disney
Princess to-date. Disney cites Belle as a role model for the mantra, "don't
judge a book by its cover."[4][51]

#### Jasmine[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Disney_Princess&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Jasmine")]

Main article: [Princess Jasmine](/wiki/Princess_Jasmine "Princess Jasmine")

[Jasmine](/wiki/Princess_Jasmine "Princess Jasmine") is the sixth Disney
Princess and the leading lady of Disney's 31st animated feature film
_[Aladdin](/wiki/Aladdin_\(1992_Disney_film\) "Aladdin \(1992 Disney film\)")_
(1992). Jasmine is fierce, bold, and confident, rarely allowing anyone to tell
her how to live her life. Jasmine hungers for independence, tired of the
restrictions laid before her by her father. She falls in love with Aladdin
while he is disguised as a prince after he takes her on a romantic ride on a
magic carpet. Aladdin's genie companion is summoned by Jafar, who uses the
genie's magic to tyrannically overthrow Jasmine's father, the Sultan. Luckily,
after Jafar's defeat, the Sultan permits Jasmine to wed Aladdin despite his
lack of royal heritage. [Princess Jasmine](/wiki/Princess_Jasmine "Princess
Jasmine") is voiced by [Linda Larkin](/wiki/Linda_Larkin "Linda Larkin"),
animated by [Mark Henn](/wiki/Mark_Henn "Mark Henn"), and her singing voice is
provided by [Lea Salonga](/wiki/Lea_Salonga "Lea Salonga") (in the feature
film) and [Liz Callaway](/wiki/Liz_Callaway "Liz Callaway") (in the [direct-
to-video](/wiki/Direct-to-video "Direct-to-video") [sequel](/wiki/Sequel
"Sequel")). [Naomi Scott](/wiki/Naomi_Scott "Naomi Scott") will star as
Jasmine in a live-action film adaptation of
_[Aladdin](/wiki/Aladdin_\(2019_film\) "Aladdin \(2019 film\)")_.[52]

Jasmine is based on [Princess Badroulbadour](/wiki/Badroulbadour
"Badroulbadour") from the [One Thousand and One
Nights](/wiki/One_Thousand_and_One_Nights "One Thousand and One Nights") tale
of "Aladdin and the Wonderful Lamp".

Jasmine is one of the first Disney princesses to identify as a minority and to
be a part of a movie taking place in an area other than Europe. While a part
of the new line of progressive princesses, shown by how Jasmine is more likely
to leave the castle and has immense curiosity about the world beyond the
palace walls, critics have judged her for her reliance on a man, sexuality
that is displayed more than in the other princesses prior, and for her false
representation of Middle Eastern culture. Her sexual depiction, particularly
in a scene where she seduces the villain [Jafar](/wiki/Jafar "Jafar"), as well
as her Western features, makes critics fear the messages Disney is spreading
about culture, as well as the continued image of women winning over men with
their bodies: "Other than skin tone, this feature appears to be the only
signifier of racial difference. In terms of the body. Jasmine, although still
small-waisted is "filmed" in more active sequences and appears, through both
the physical presence and activity in scenes, more athletic."[33] Disney
claims its intention with Jasmine is to inspire viewers to "see the good in
others."[53]

####
Pocahontas[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Disney_Princess&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Pocahontas")]

Main article: [Pocahontas (character)](/wiki/Pocahontas_\(character\)
"Pocahontas \(character\)")

[Pocahontas](/wiki/Pocahontas_\(character\) "Pocahontas \(character\)") is the
seventh Disney Princess and first appeared in Disney's 33rd animated feature
film _[Pocahontas](/wiki/Pocahontas_\(1995_film\) "Pocahontas \(1995 film\)")_
(1995). Based on the Native American chief's daughter,
[Pocahontas](/wiki/Pocahontas "Pocahontas") (c. 1595–1617), and the settlement
of [Jamestown, Virginia](/wiki/Jamestown,_Virginia "Jamestown, Virginia") in
1607. Pocahontas is displayed as a noble, independent and highly spiritual
young woman. She expresses wisdom beyond her years and offers kindness and
guidance to those around her. An adventurer and nature lover, in the film she
appears to have shamanic powers since she was able to communicate with nature,
spirits, and animals and understand foreign languages. In the sequel,
Pocahontas, after hearing of John Smith's assumed death, is heartbroken.
Despite this, she keeps her independent spirit and playfulness and is even
much more mature and self-assured than she was in the first film. During her
stay in England, she nearly loses herself in the hustle and bustle of the new
world, consequently falling victim to western culture assimilation. But in the
end, she bravely intends to sacrifice herself for her people's safety and
returns to her homeland, finding herself, and love, once again. She was voiced
by [Irene Bedard](/wiki/Irene_Bedard "Irene Bedard") and animated by [Glen
Keane](/wiki/Glen_Keane "Glen Keane") while her singing was provided by [Judy
Kuhn](/wiki/Judy_Kuhn "Judy Kuhn").

Like Jasmine, Pocahontas, and her film, are criticized for the depiction of
over-sexualized females in a culturally diverse world. Both princesses are
shown with small waists, large almond eyes, and incredible athletic ability
that none of the other, caucasian Disney princesses represent. Further, the
film has been met with criticism from the Native American community as
heralding colonialism and an invalid, romanticized representation of an
important figure to the Powhatan people. In terms of its 90s debut, Buescher
and Ono in their critical review of the film claim that Pocahontas's actions,
"appropriates contemporary social issues of feminism, environmentalism, and
human freedom in order to make racial domination appear innocent and
pure."[54] Despite these issues, Pocahontas is the first Disney Princess to
not continue her romantic relationship at the conclusion of the film and even
plays a direct role in rescuing her lover, John Smith. She is considered to be
one of the most independent Disney princesses.[55] Disney claims Pocahontas as
a role model to "respect the earth."[4] Pocahontas is the first Disney
Princess based on a real person.

#### Mulan[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Disney_Princess&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Mulan")]

Main article: [Mulan (Disney character)](/wiki/Mulan_\(Disney_character\)
"Mulan \(Disney character\)")

[Fa Mulan](/wiki/Mulan_\(Disney_character\) "Mulan \(Disney character\)"), or
simply Mulan is the eighth Disney Princess[56] and first appeared in Disney's
36th animated feature film _[Mulan](/wiki/Mulan_\(1998_film\) "Mulan \(1998
film\)")_ (1998). The movie is adapted from the legend of [Hua
Mulan](/wiki/Hua_Mulan "Hua Mulan") (6th century; 'Northern and Southern
Dynasties' period). Mulan, atypical and unlike most previous female roles, is
courageous and more self-reliant. She also does not fit in with the
expectations of a young Chinese girl of the time; despite her natural beauty,
she is clumsy, outspoken, and independent rather than graceful, silent and
demure. After her meeting with the matchmaker ended in chaos, the matchmaker
claimed that even though she had the looks of a bride, she would never find a
match. However, her courage, intelligence, and determination helped her
through her adventures, in which she disguises herself as a male soldier in
order to fight in the Chinese army in place of her wounded father. She was
voiced by [Ming-Na Wen](/wiki/Ming-Na_Wen "Ming-Na Wen") and animated by [Mark
Henn](/wiki/Mark_Henn "Mark Henn") while her singing was provided by [Lea
Salonga](/wiki/Lea_Salonga "Lea Salonga"). [Liu Yifei](/wiki/Liu_Yifei "Liu
Yifei") is set to portray Mulan in a live-action adaptation of the 1998
animated film.[57]

Mulan saves her people and is the hero of her own story. Because of this, many
see Mulan as a positive role model in her determination, risk-taking, and her
conclusion of saving all of China.[55] Disney promotes Mulan as role model who
can help "find your inner warrior."[4]

### Modern
era[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Disney_Princess&action=edit&section=15 "Edit
section: Modern era")]

#### Tiana[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Disney_Princess&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Tiana")]

Main article: [Tiana (Disney)](/wiki/Tiana_\(Disney\) "Tiana \(Disney\)")

[Tiana](/wiki/Tiana_\(Disney\) "Tiana \(Disney\)"), voiced by [Anika Noni
Rose](/wiki/Anika_Noni_Rose "Anika Noni Rose") and animated by [Mark
Henn](/wiki/Mark_Henn "Mark Henn"), is the ninth Disney Princess character to
be incorporated into the franchise, appearing in Disney's 49th animated
feature film _[The Princess and the Frog](/wiki/The_Princess_and_the_Frog "The
Princess and the Frog")_ (2009). Her film is loosely based on the novel _[The
Frog Princess](/wiki/The_Frog_Princess_\(novel\) "The Frog Princess
\(novel\)")_ by [E. D. Baker](/wiki/E._D._Baker "E. D. Baker"), which is in
turn based on the Brothers Grimm fairy tale _[The Frog
Prince](/wiki/The_Frog_Prince_\(story\) "The Frog Prince \(story\)")_. Tiana
is portrayed as being a hardworking, ambitious, and beautiful young woman who
has no love interest (at the start of the film). Living in New Orleans,
Louisiana, Tiana strives to achieve her goal of opening her own restaurant (an
ambition inspired by the accomplishments of real-life restaurateur [Leah
Chase](/wiki/Leah_Chase "Leah Chase")).[58] However, she is transformed into a
frog after trying to break a spell cast by a Bokor on Prince Naveen that had
changed him into a frog also. Throughout the film, the pair must embark on a
quest to find a way to break the spell. Tiana was officially "coronated" and
became a member of the Disney Princess line-up on March 14, 2010, at the [New
York Palace Hotel](/wiki/Lotte_New_York_Palace_Hotel "Lotte New York Palace
Hotel") in [Manhattan, New York](/wiki/Manhattan,_New_York "Manhattan, New
York").[11]

Tiana marks the first princess in the "fourth-wave" feminist movement that
initiated the most modern line of Disney films, including movies like
_Tangled_ , _Brave_ and _Frozen_. Unlike her past counterparts, Tiana has
received more praise than criticism for her depiction of female independence
and of minority culture. Christopher Lehman, author of "The Colored Cartoon,"
claims that, "Princess and the Frog" [i]s a step in the right direction
because it deviates from those polarized caricatures with characters that are
crafted with individuality," those characters being either "mammy" or over
sexualized versions of female African Americans. Instead, Tiana offers a new
perspective as simply a hard-working woman who bears no reliance on a man.[59]
Disney says Tiana represents "mak[ing] a dream real."[4]

#### Rapunzel[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Disney_Princess&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: Rapunzel")]

Main article: [Rapunzel (Disney)](/wiki/Rapunzel_\(Disney\) "Rapunzel
\(Disney\)")

[Rapunzel](/wiki/Rapunzel_\(Disney\) "Rapunzel \(Disney\)") is the tenth
Disney Princess. First appearing in Disney's 50th animated feature film
_[Tangled](/wiki/Tangled "Tangled")_ (2010), Rapunzel is based on the heroine
of the [German fairy tale](/wiki/Rapunzel "Rapunzel") by the [Brothers
Grimm](/wiki/Brothers_Grimm "Brothers Grimm"). Created by screenwriter [Dan
Fogelman](/wiki/Dan_Fogelman "Dan Fogelman"),
[Rapunzel](/wiki/Rapunzel_\(Disney\) "Rapunzel \(Disney\)") was originally
animated by [Glen Keane](/wiki/Glen_Keane "Glen Keane") and is voiced by
recording artist and actress [Mandy Moore](/wiki/Mandy_Moore "Mandy Moore").
The character was "[coronated](/wiki/Coronate "Coronate")" and inducted into
the Disney Princess franchise on October 2, 2011, at [Kensington
Palace](/wiki/Kensington_Palace "Kensington Palace") in [London,
England](/wiki/London,_England "London, England").[13][60][61]

A princess born with long, magical golden hair, Rapunzel, stolen from her
parents, the King and Queen of Corona, at infancy, is raised by [Mother
Gothel](/wiki/Mother_Gothel "Mother Gothel"), an evil and vain old woman and
exploits her hair to remain young and beautiful. Incarcerated in an isolated
tower for eighteen years, Rapunzel enlists the help of a wanted thief named
[Flynn Rider](/wiki/Flynn_Rider "Flynn Rider") to see the floating lanterns in
time for her 18th birthday.

Rapunzel is notably the first Disney Princess to appear in a
[CGI](/wiki/Computer-generated_imagery "Computer-generated imagery") film but
is frequently revamped to a traditionally animated design when appearing in
merchandising alongside fellow, classically animated Princesses.

The character has been generally well received by most critics. Particular
praise was awarded to her spirited personality and contemporaneity. The _[Los
Angeles Times](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Times "Los Angeles Times")_ described
Rapunzel as "a very modern young woman".[62] _[The New
Yorker](/wiki/The_New_Yorker "The New Yorker")_ called Rapunzel a witty and
intelligent character,[63] while _[USA Today](/wiki/USA_Today "USA Today")_
wrote, "Rapunzel is more believable in her teenage histrionics" than previous
Disney heroines.[64] However, some reviews, such as the two provided by _[Time
Out](/wiki/Time_Out_\(magazine\) "Time Out \(magazine\)")_ , were less
favorable in their opinions of the character, describing her as both a
"bland"[65] and "synthetic" character.[66] Disney describes her as promoting
"jump[ing] into new adventures."[4]

#### Merida[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Disney_Princess&action=edit&section=18
"Edit section: Merida")]

Main article: [Merida (Disney)](/wiki/Merida_\(Disney\) "Merida \(Disney\)")

[Merida](/wiki/Merida_\(Disney\) "Merida \(Disney\)") is the eleventh Disney
princess, first appearing in the [Pixar](/wiki/Pixar "Pixar") film
_[Brave](/wiki/Brave_\(2012_film\) "Brave \(2012 film\)")_ (2012).[3] Voiced
by [Kelly Macdonald](/wiki/Kelly_Macdonald "Kelly Macdonald"), the character's
singing voice is provided by [Julie Fowlis](/wiki/Julie_Fowlis "Julie
Fowlis"). She was created by director and screenwriter [Brenda
Chapman](/wiki/Brenda_Chapman "Brenda Chapman"). Merida is the 16-year-old
daughter of Queen Elinor, who rules the kingdom alongside King Fergus. Queen
Elinor's expectations of her daughter make Merida see her mother as being
distant while also causing friction between the two. Despite Elinor's desire
to see Merida as a proper royal lady, Merida is an impetuous girl who wants to
take control of her own destiny. She has honed her skill in archery and is one
of the most skilled archers ever seen. She is also skilled in sword-fighting
and cross-country horse riding on her horse, Angus. Merida was "coronated" and
officially became a part of the Disney Princess franchise on May 11, 2013, at
[Walt Disney World](/wiki/Walt_Disney_World "Walt Disney World")'s [Magic
Kingdom](/wiki/Magic_Kingdom "Magic Kingdom").[67]

She is the first Disney princess in the line-up to not have a love interest in
her film, and the first to not sing in her film. Further, her stubbornness and
independence have generally resonated with feminists, as well as her near
entire rejection of "princess duties" like marrying a man and looking
proper.[68] She is also the first [Pixar](/wiki/Pixar "Pixar") and the second
CGI princess. By her actions throughout the film, Disney makes Merida the
spokesperson of bravery.[4]

## Portrayals in culture and
media[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Disney_Princess&action=edit&section=19 "Edit
section: Portrayals in culture and media")]

### Theme park
rides[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Disney_Princess&action=edit&section=20 "Edit
section: Theme park rides")]

####
Disneyland[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Disney_Princess&action=edit&section=21
"Edit section: Disneyland")]

Ariel has an attraction at the [California
Adventure](/wiki/Disney_California_Adventure "Disney California Adventure")
park called "[Ariel's Undersea
Adventure](/wiki/The_Little_Mermaid:_Ariel%27s_Undersea_Adventure "The Little
Mermaid: Ariel's Undersea Adventure")" which opened June 3, 2011.[69] Guests
in Paradise Pier hop in the "clam-mobile" and are taken under the sea into
Ariel's world.[70]

Snow White has her own ride at [Disneyland](/wiki/Disneyland "Disneyland"),
[Tokyo Disneyland](/wiki/Tokyo_Disneyland "Tokyo Disneyland") and [Disneyland
Paris](/wiki/Disneyland_Paris "Disneyland Paris") known as "[Snow White's
Scary Adventures](/wiki/Snow_White%27s_Scary_Adventures "Snow White's Scary
Adventures")".

#### Walt Disney
World[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Disney_Princess&action=edit&section=22 "Edit
section: Walt Disney World")]

The "[Snow White's Scary Adventures](/wiki/Snow_White%27s_Scary_Adventures
"Snow White's Scary Adventures")" ride was also featured at the [Walt Disney
World Resort](/wiki/Walt_Disney_World_Resort "Walt Disney World Resort"),
however, it was removed in 2012 as part of the [New
Fantasyland](/wiki/New_Fantasyland "New Fantasyland") expansion.[71]

An attraction opened in the [Magic Kingdom](/wiki/Magic_Kingdom "Magic
Kingdom")'s [New Fantasyland](/wiki/Fantasyland "Fantasyland") entitled
"Enchanted Tales with Belle" on December 6, 2012.[72] The 20-minute attraction
takes guests into Maurice's cottage to meet Belle and reenact the story of the
_Beauty and the Beast._

_[Under the Sea: Journey of the Little
Mermaid](/wiki/The_Little_Mermaid:_Ariel%27s_Undersea_Adventure "The Little
Mermaid: Ariel's Undersea Adventure")_ , which is based on Disneyland's _The
Little Mermaid: Ariel 's Undersea Adventure_, opened on December 6, 2012.[73]
The Magic Kingdom attraction has a different exterior and queue than the one
in Disneyland.

On May 28, 2014, the "[Seven Dwarfs Mine Train](/wiki/Seven_Dwarfs_Mine_Train
"Seven Dwarfs Mine Train")" opened in [Magic Kingdom](/wiki/Magic_Kingdom
"Magic Kingdom") at the [Walt Disney World Resort](/wiki/Walt_Disney_World
"Walt Disney World").[74] The 2,000-foot long steel roller coaster averages a
speed of 34 mph and features two drops peaking at 41 feet. "Just like in
_[Snow White and the Seven
Dwarfs](/wiki/Snow_White_and_the_Seven_Dwarfs_\(1937_film\) "Snow White and
the Seven Dwarfs \(1937 film\)")_ , make your merry way across the rolling
stone bridges and through a forest where you’ll find the Dwarfs’ cottage and
all the stars from the film."[75] Riders are brought through the classic tale
in a runaway mine train alongside the Dwarfs through the forest, by the
cottage, and into the diamond mine of the Dwarfs. The mine cave features what
Disney Imagineers say are "some of the most advanced _Audio-Animatronics
characters_ ever created."[76]

Resort](/wiki/Disneyland_Resort "Disneyland Resort") in California.
Additionally, In 2006, as part of the "Year of Million Dreams" celebration,
the [Fantasyland Theater](/wiki/Fantasyland_Theatre "Fantasyland Theatre")
began hosting the _Disneyland Princess Fantasy Faire,_ a show featuring Lords
and Ladies that taught young boys and girls the proper etiquette to be a
prince or princess and features appearances from the Disney Princesses. In
2010, Rapunzel was given a _Tangled_ meet-and-greet location. The Carnation
Plaza Gardens bandstand, adjacent to Sleeping Beauty Castle, was closed to be
replaced by a new Fantasy Faire area in the Spring of 2013.[77]

The Fantasy Faire area in Disneyland officially opened on March 12, 2013, as
the permanent home for the Disney Princesses and consists of a Royal Hall, a
Royal Theatre, Maurice's Treats food cart and Fairytale Treasures gift
shop.[78][79] The theater features two small shows based on _Beauty and the
Beast_ and _Tangled_. The hall is used for meet and greets with the
princesses, which have a rotation schedule with three princesses scheduled to
appear at a time.[78]

#### Walt Disney
World[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Disney_Princess&action=edit&section=26 "Edit
section: Walt Disney World")]

At [Walt Disney World Resort](/wiki/Walt_Disney_World_Resort "Walt Disney
World Resort"), the princesses are available for meet-and-greets in more
specific locations. Cinderella-based character dining and interaction, located
at _Cinderella 's Royal Table_ in her [Magic Kingdom](/wiki/Magic_Kingdom
"Magic Kingdom") castle, as well as "Cinderella's Happily Ever After Dinner,"
(formerly known as the _Cinderella 's Gala Feast Dinner_) at 1900 Park Fare in
the [Disney's Grand Floridian Resort &
Spa](/wiki/Disney%27s_Grand_Floridian_Resort_%26_Spa "Disney's Grand Floridian
Resort & Spa") are common places for Cinderella and other Disney characters to
appear. The Princesses also can be found at the Princess Storybook meal at
[Epcot](/wiki/Epcot "Epcot"). On September 18, 2013, a new meet-and-greet
attraction called _Princess Fairytale Hall_ opened at the [Magic
Kingdom](/wiki/Magic_Kingdom "Magic Kingdom").[78][80][81]

Many shows and parades across the property feature the princesses, including
_[Fantasmic](/wiki/Fantasmic "Fantasmic")_ , _[Main Street Electrical
Parade](/wiki/Main_Street_Electrical_Parade "Main Street Electrical Parade")_
, _Dream Along with Mickey_ , the _Festival of Fantasy Parade_ , _Mickey 's
Boo-to-You Halloween Parade_ and _Mickey 's Once Upon a Christmastime Parade_.
A store named "Bibbidi Bobbidi Boutique" opened April 5, 2006, at the World of
Disney store in Downtown Disney (now [Disney Springs](/wiki/Disney_Springs
"Disney Springs")) at Walt Disney World; this shop allows children to receive
princess makeovers. A second location opened in [Cinderella
Castle](/wiki/Cinderella_Castle "Cinderella Castle") on September 10, 2007.

On January 22, 2007, the [Magic Kingdom](/wiki/Magic_Kingdom "Magic Kingdom")
at [Walt Disney World Resort](/wiki/Walt_Disney_World_Resort "Walt Disney
World Resort") began its first _Pirate and Princess Party_. This hard ticketed
event featured "Disney's Enchanted Adventures Parade" and a specially themed
fireworks spectacular called "[Magic, Music and
Mayhem](/wiki/Magic,_Music_and_Mayhem "Magic, Music and Mayhem")". The parade
featured the six main Princesses attended by knights and dancers. Each land is
themed accordingly to a pirate or princess, such as Jasmine's Court in
[Adventureland](/wiki/Adventureland_\(Disney\) "Adventureland \(Disney\)"),
Ariel's Court in [Fantasyland](/wiki/Fantasyland "Fantasyland") and the
Princess Pavilion in Mickey's Toontown Fair. This event has since been
discontinued.

#### Shanghai
Disneyland[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Disney_Princess&action=edit&section=27
"Edit section: Shanghai Disneyland")]

A Princess meet and greet location called Once Upon a Time was operational at
[Shanghai Disneyland](/wiki/Shanghai_Disneyland "Shanghai Disneyland")'s
opening and is located at Storybook Castle.[78]

### Films and
television[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Disney_Princess&action=edit&section=28
"Edit section: Films and television")]

The Disney Princesses' television appearances were compiled into the _Disney
Princess Collection_ , a series of compilation DVDs containing episodes from
_[Aladdin](/wiki/Aladdin_\(TV_series\) "Aladdin \(TV series\)")_ , _[The
Little Mermaid](/wiki/The_Little_Mermaid_\(TV_series\) "The Little Mermaid
\(TV series\)")_ and two _Beauty and the Beast_ specials. A later DVD series
was released, entitled _Disney Princess Stories_ , featuring content similar
to the previous release. _Princess Party Palace_ (formerly known as _The
Princess Power Hour_) was a programming block on [Toon Disney](/wiki/Disney_XD
"Disney XD") from 2000 until 2007 and where it used to air episodes of _The
Little Mermaid_ and _Aladdin_.

Belle had her own live-action television series called _[Sing Me a Story with
Belle](/wiki/Sing_Me_a_Story_with_Belle "Sing Me a Story with Belle")_. The
first eight Disney Princesses also made appearances on the animated TV series
_[House of Mouse](/wiki/Disney%27s_House_of_Mouse "Disney's House of Mouse")_
and Belle also made an appearance (along with her husband, Beast) on a short
episode from the TV animated series _[Mickey
Mouse](/wiki/Mickey_Mouse_\(TV_series\) "Mickey Mouse \(TV series\)")_.

In early 2007, Disney announced _Disney Princess Enchanted Tales_ , a new
series of [direct-to-video](/wiki/Direct-to-video "Direct-to-video") features
that feature new stories for the Disney Princesses. The first movie in the
series entitled _[Disney Princess Enchanted Tales: Follow Your
Dreams](/wiki/Disney_Princess_Enchanted_Tales:_Follow_Your_Dreams "Disney
Princess Enchanted Tales: Follow Your Dreams")_ , was released on September 4,
2007. It is a musical film featuring new tales about Princess Jasmine and the
first new tale about Princess Aurora since the original _Sleeping Beauty_.

Originally, _Disney Princess Enchanted Tales: A Kingdom of Kindness_ was
announced as the first film in the series, which contained a different
Princess Aurora story, and had a Belle story rather than a Princess Jasmine
story. Disney made this change without any sort of notice.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]
Currently,[_[when?](/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items
"Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers")_] the series is cancelled and
only "Follow Your Dreams" exists.[82]

The TV series _[Once Upon a Time](/wiki/Once_Upon_a_Time_\(TV_Series\) "Once
Upon a Time \(TV Series\)")_ that airs on the Disney-owned
[ABC](/wiki/American_Broadcasting_Company "American Broadcasting Company"),
featured live-action versions of Snow White, Cinderella, Belle, Aurora, Mulan,
Ariel, Rapunzel, Merida, Jasmine and Tiana in addition to Anna and Elsa. Snow
White and Belle were previously main characters while the rest made recurring
and or guest appearances. Beginning in season 7, Cinderella, Tiana and
Rapunzel were main characters. Many of these characters are patterned after
the Disney versions, but a few draw inspiration from older stories.

The TV series _[Sofia the First](/wiki/Sofia_the_First "Sofia the First")_
premiered on January 11, 2013, on [Disney Junior](/wiki/Disney_Junior "Disney
Junior"); to
date,[_[when?](/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items
"Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers")_] Cinderella appeared in the
first movie _Once Upon A Princess_. Princesses Jasmine, Belle, Aurora, Snow
White, Mulan, Tiana, and Merida have appeared on the show, and Ariel and
Rapunzel appeared in the TV Specials _The Floating Palace_ and _The Curse of
Princess Ivy_ , respectively. There are plans to feature Pocahontas and
[Moana](/wiki/Moana_\(2016_film\) "Moana \(2016 film\)") in future episodes.
However, Sofia is a minor princess and not in the royal court. She is voiced
by _[Modern Family](/wiki/Modern_Family "Modern Family")_ star [Ariel
Winter](/wiki/Ariel_Winter "Ariel Winter").

In the 2014 film _[Maleficent](/wiki/Maleficent_\(film\) "Maleficent
\(film\)")_ , Aurora is played by [Elle Fanning](/wiki/Elle_Fanning "Elle
Fanning"). [Lily James](/wiki/Lily_James "Lily James") portrays Cinderella in
the [2015 film of the same name](/wiki/Cinderella_\(2015_Disney_film\)
"Cinderella \(2015 Disney film\)"). [Emma Watson](/wiki/Emma_Watson "Emma
Watson") is seen as Belle in the 2017 film _[Beauty and the
Beast](/wiki/Beauty_and_the_Beast_\(2017_film\) "Beauty and the Beast \(2017
film\)")_. [Naomi Scott](/wiki/Naomi_Scott "Naomi Scott") is set to star as
Jasmine in the upcoming film _[Aladdin](/wiki/Aladdin_\(2019_film\) "Aladdin
\(2019 film\)")_.[83] [Liu Yifei](/wiki/Liu_Yifei "Liu Yifei") has been cast
as Mulan in an upcoming live-action adaptation of the 1998 film.[84]

The Princesses, along with Anna, Elsa and Moana, will make a cameo appearance
in _[Ralph Breaks the Internet: Wreck-It Ralph
2](/wiki/Ralph_Breaks_the_Internet:_Wreck-It_Ralph_2 "Ralph Breaks the
Internet: Wreck-It Ralph 2")_. This will mark the first time the princesses
would be interacting with each other in a feature film on-screen.[85]

### Comic
adaptation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Disney_Princess&action=edit&section=32
"Edit section: Comic adaptation")]

In _[Kilala Princess](/wiki/Kilala_Princess "Kilala Princess")_ , a Japanese
fantasy/romance [manga](/wiki/Manga "Manga") produced by
[Kodansha](/wiki/Kodansha "Kodansha") that debuted in
[Nakayoshi](/wiki/Nakayoshi "Nakayoshi") in April 2005. The plot of the manga
revolves around a girl named Kilala and her adventures to find her kidnapped
friend with the help of the first six Disney Princesses, who are Snow White,
Cinderella, Aurora, Ariel, Belle, and Jasmine, though Kilala herself isn't
considered part of the franchise.

### Video
games[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Disney_Princess&action=edit&section=33 "Edit
section: Video games")]

Disney Princesses have appeared in various other media, such as video games,
including _[Disney Princess: Enchanted
Journey](/wiki/Disney_Princess:_Enchanted_Journey "Disney Princess: Enchanted
Journey")_ , _[Disney Princess: Magical
Jewels](/wiki/Disney_Princess:_Magical_Jewels "Disney Princess: Magical
Jewels")_ , and _[Disney Princess: My Fairytale
Adventure](/wiki/Disney_Princess:_My_Fairytale_Adventure "Disney Princess: My
Fairytale Adventure")_.[86] Rapunzel can be found as a character in the 2013
game _[Disney Infinity](/wiki/Disney_Infinity_\(video_game\) "Disney Infinity
\(video game\)")_ along with other non-franchise princesses.
[Anna](/wiki/Anna_\(Disney\) "Anna \(Disney\)") and
[Elsa](/wiki/Elsa_\(Disney\) "Elsa \(Disney\)") are also included but are not
officially part of the Disney Princess Royal Court. _[Disney Infinity: 2.0
Edition](/wiki/Disney_Infinity:_Marvel_Super_Heroes "Disney Infinity: Marvel
Super Heroes")_ has the addition of Merida and Jasmine. However, Merida is
also included with [Stitch](/wiki/Stitch_\(Lilo_%26_Stitch\) "Stitch \(Lilo &
Stitch\)") in the Toy Box Starter Pack. _[Disney Infinity
3.0](/wiki/Disney_Infinity_3.0 "Disney Infinity 3.0")_ includes the character
[Mulan](/wiki/Mulan_\(Disney_character\) "Mulan \(Disney character\)").

#### Kingdom
Hearts[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Disney_Princess&action=edit&section=34 "Edit
section: Kingdom Hearts")]

In the _[Kingdom Hearts](/wiki/Kingdom_Hearts "Kingdom Hearts")_ game series,
the seven "[Princesses of Heart](/wiki/Princesses_of_Heart "Princesses of
Heart")", are young ladies with entirely pure hearts who would open the way to
Kingdom Hearts if gathered together. Five of these maidens- Cinderella, Belle,
Aurora, Snow White and Jasmine are Disney Princesses. The remaining Princesses
of Heart are [Alice](/wiki/Portrayals_of_Alice_in_Wonderland "Portrayals of
Alice in Wonderland") from _[Alice in
Wonderland](/wiki/Alice_in_Wonderland_\(1951_film\) "Alice in Wonderland
\(1951 film\)")_ and game series' heroine,
[Kairi](/wiki/Kairi_\(Kingdom_Hearts\) "Kairi \(Kingdom Hearts\)"), though the
latter is only exclusive to the video game like Kilala. The Disney Princesses
make various appearances throughout the series:

  * While all seven Princesses of Heart and all then-six Disney princesses appear in the first game, only Belle, Ariel, and Jasmine reappeared in _[Kingdom Hearts II](/wiki/Kingdom_Hearts_II "Kingdom Hearts II")_ with Kairi, though the others are mentioned. Mulan, however, makes her first appearance as the player visits her world. She serves as a tradeable character in the party similarly to how Ariel was in the first _[Kingdom Hearts](/wiki/Kingdom_Hearts "Kingdom Hearts")_.
  * Belle, Jasmine, Ariel and Alice appear in _[Kingdom Hearts: Chain of Memories](/wiki/Kingdom_Hearts:_Chain_of_Memories "Kingdom Hearts: Chain of Memories")_ as figments of Sora's memory, but their roles as Princesses of Heart are not brought up; they also appear in _Kingdom Hearts: 358/2 Days_ when they each meet Roxas.
  * In the prequel _[Kingdom Hearts Birth by Sleep](/wiki/Kingdom_Hearts_Birth_by_Sleep "Kingdom Hearts Birth by Sleep")_ , Snow White, Cinderella and Aurora appear as the game's playable characters assume prominent positions in the princesses' original stories.
  * Digital versions of Alice and Jasmine appear in _[Kingdom Hearts coded](/wiki/Kingdom_Hearts_coded "Kingdom Hearts coded")_.[87]

## Reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Disney_Princess&action=edit&section=35
"Edit section: Reception")]

The Disney Princess franchise has received mixed reception from critics and
parents, particularity [feminists](/wiki/Feminist "Feminist").

### Ethnic
reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Disney_Princess&action=edit&section=36
"Edit section: Ethnic reception")]

_[Pocahontas](/wiki/Pocahontas_\(1995_film\) "Pocahontas \(1995 film\)")_ was
criticized by [University of Puget Sound](/wiki/University_of_Puget_Sound
"University of Puget Sound") Communications Professor Derek Buescher and
[University of Utah](/wiki/University_of_Utah "University of Utah") Professor
of Communication Kent Ono. In their paper _Civilized Colonialism: Pocahontas
as a Neocolonial Rhetoric_ , they call the film as an attempt to justify and
purify colonization which implies that all Native American people are
"savages" that are in need of white assimilation.[54] Reception to Disney's
first African-American princess, Tiana, the star of _The Princess and the
Frog_ , was mostly positive, and considered "a step in the right direction."
However, the film's New Orleans setting in the wake of [Hurricane
Katrina](/wiki/Hurricane_Katrina "Hurricane Katrina") and references to
[voodoo](/wiki/Louisiana_Voodoo "Louisiana Voodoo") drew criticism from
parents and the media, as did Tiana's romance with a "Caucasian" prince.[88]
Tiana's love interest, Prince Naveen, has brown skin[89] and has been
interpreted as a non-white character.[90] According to a Disney executive,
Naveen's "background was made up; he's whatever ethnicity they have in
[Naveen's] fictional [homeland of] Maldonia."[89]

### Feminist
reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Disney_Princess&action=edit&section=37
"Edit section: Feminist reception")]

Tension has been present between The Walt Disney Company and feminists ever
since the release of _[Snow White and the Seven
Dwarfs](/wiki/Snow_White_and_the_Seven_Dwarfs_\(1937_film\) "Snow White and
the Seven Dwarfs \(1937 film\)")_ in 1937.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] The
type of representations of women in Disney films reflect [Walt
Disney](/wiki/Walt_Disney "Walt Disney")'s personal feelings about family
life, which in turn also shaped the Disney Company.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] Another
influence was the fact that Disney's attitudes mirrored the patriarchal
cultural beliefs of the 1940s about what roles women should play in
society.[91]

On December 24, 2006, [Peggy Orenstein](/wiki/Peggy_Orenstein "Peggy
Orenstein") published "What's Wrong With Cinderella?" in _[The New York
Times](/wiki/The_New_York_Times "The New York Times")_. In her article,
Orenstein discussed her concerns about the effects of princess figures on
young girls. Orenstein used the Disney Princesses specifically to present many
of her points. Orenstein also noted the pervasive nature of Princess
merchandise and that every facet of play has its princess equivalent.[7]
Tamara Weston of _Time_ magazine criticized the franchise, referring to the
princesses as "[damsels in distress](/wiki/Damsel_in_distress "Damsel in
distress")" and negative role models for young girls.[92] Anna Smith of _The
Guardian_ disliked that Disney princesses were typically drawn with slender
figures and large eyes.[93] Other sources have also voiced concern that the
franchise could possibly give young girls the wrong message.[94] However,
other parents who have young daughters say that they would eventually grow out
of this phase.[95]

Many articles describe Disney Princesses as the beginnings of feminism. In the
[Bustle](/wiki/Bustle_\(magazine\) "Bustle \(magazine\)") article "A Feminist
Ranking Of All The Disney Princesses, Because Not Every Princess Was Down For
Waiting For Anyone To Rescue Her," [Chelsea
Maze](http://www.bustle.com/articles/101274-a-feminist-ranking-of-all-the-
disney-princesses-because-not-every-princess-was-down-for-waiting) ranks
Disney Princesses and how each one contributes to feminism in her own way. The
first princess is Mulan and the last one is Aurora. These ranks connect to how
they contribute to the man's needs and also the main story plot in the
films.[96]

Another recent article from [Cracked.com](/wiki/Cracked.com "Cracked.com")
explains how the Disney Princesses have always been feminist and has a deeper
explanation as to how they are feminist. Kristi Harrison explains in her
article "4 Ways Disney Princesses Created Modern Feminism". She explains how
we should think of the princesses as protagonists instead of princesses. Most
of their adventures began with the recognition that most of their adventures
began with rebellion against the patriarchy.[97]

Another article from Highbrow Magazine titled "How Fourth-Wave Feminism is
Changing Disney Princesses" explains how the connection of feminism and Disney
Princesses and the waves of feminism shape the way film and TV illustrate
women. The first wave of feminism took place during the time the first three
Disney princess films were produced. As said in the article, for these
original Disney princesses, their beauty is their most defining
characteristic. In all three films, the prince falls in love with and
saves/marries the princess based solely on her appearance. These princesses
are beautiful women and suffer because of circumstances out of their control
and finally find salvation in the love of a powerful man.[98]

Kaitlin Eberson, the author of the article, explains how the second waved of
feminism that lasted until the 1980s went hand in hand with the civil rights
movement and focused on women’s legal and social equality. During this time
Ariel, Belle, Jasmine, Pocahontas, and Mulan illustrated the ideology of
society’s drastically altered beliefs about who women are and how they should
act, as each princess has a distinct personality.[98]

The earlier Disney princess films were criticized for their representation of
domestication, romance, and dependence on a male hero. The next wave of Disney
princess films, part of the so-called 'Progressive' Disney of the studio's
renaissance era of animation, attempted to make more independent female
characters, though romance still played a large role in all of these films.
There was a long-time gap between the releases of _Mulan_ and _The Princess
and the Frog_ , but the fourth wave of feminism discusses the issues faced by
women and how women acknowledged the inequality between genders. During this
wave, the films showed strong, independent women that were powerful and were
not submissive to a patriarchal society.[98]

[A. O. Scott](/wiki/A._O._Scott "A. O. Scott") of _[The New York
Times](/wiki/The_New_York_Times "The New York Times")_ in 2016 described the
"feisty" and "battle-ready" [Princess Leia](/wiki/Princess_Leia "Princess
Leia") as "a foremother of [Hermione Granger](/wiki/Hermione_Granger "Hermione
Granger") and [Katniss Everdeen](/wiki/Katniss_Everdeen "Katniss Everdeen")
and of countless latter-day Disney princesses".[99] Studies evaluating the
prevalence of classic male and female qualities represented by varying
characters in Disney animated films showed that the earlier films tended to
have more of the female characters displaying feminine characteristics at 86%,
while the middle films were more along the lines of 58%. _The Princess and the
Frog_ alone had 53% of feminine qualities featured in its films in comparison
to male characteristics, showing the progression that Disney has undergone in
terms of feminism and escaping gendered norms.[31] There is little data on the
most recent films; however, general viewer reception has been positive in
regards to the "feminist" qualities that these princesses display.[100]
